name: diammonium phosphate production | diammonium phosphate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23404/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of diammonium phosphate (DAP) with 18% N and 46% P2O5. Diammonium phosphate is a compound fertiliser used to enrich the soil in nitrogen (N) and phosphorous (P), two of the main macronutrients needed to support plant growth.;Diammonium phosphate is produced through the neutralisation of phosphoric acid by gaseous ammonia. The production process has gone through a series of development phases, from atmospheric neutralisation in tanks with agitators, to pressure neutralisation and more recently to pipe reactors in the granulator and/or the dryer. The latter is the most energy efficient and is considered state of the art today. Phosphoric acid and ammonia are used in a granulation unit with a pipe reactor to produce the diammonium phosphate.;Diammonium phosphate has other applications besides its use as fertiliser. DAP can be used as a fire retardant, as a yeast nutrient in winemaking and mead-making, in purifying sugar, and as a flux for soldering tin, copper, zinc and brass.;The main data sources for this dataset are Fertilizers Europe (2000, 2016). Additional data sources are listed as follows.;References:;Fertilizers Europe (2000): Best Available Techniques for Pollution Prevention and Control in the European Fertilizer Industry. Booklet No. 1 of 8: Production of Ammonia. Fertilizers Europe, Brussels.;Kongshaug G. (1998): Energy Consumption and Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Fertilizer Production. IFA 20th July 1998;Davies J., Haglund C. (1999): Life Cycle Inventory of Fertiliser Production. SIK-Report No 654 1999. Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden.;Fertilizers Europe (2016): Carbon Footprint Calculator for Fertilizer Production. Specification. Version 2.1;Fertilizers Europe (2016): Average Emissions Year 2014. Fertilizers Europe Environmental report (internal). Used for updated energy and GHG emission in Carbon Footprint Calculator;Fertilizers Europe (2000): Best Available Techniques for Pollution Prevention and Control in the European Fertilizer Industry. Booklet No. 3 of 8: Production of Sulphuric Acid. Fertilizers Europe, Brussels.;Fertilizers Europe (2000): Best Available Techniques for Pollution Prevention and Control in the European Fertilizer Industry. Booklet No. 4 of 8: Production of Phosphoric Acid. Fertilizers Europe, Brussels.;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

The activity includes all the raw and processed materials necessary to produce this product. Liquid ammonia, phosphoric acid, heat (as natural gas), steam and electricity are included. Direct emissions include ammonia and particulate matter to air and phosphorous to water.

The activity ends with the final product being ready for transportation at the production site.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Primary data were collected on fertiliser production for the year 2011. These data were based on annual average data for the year 2011.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The dataset is representative of DAP production in China, adapted from data collected in European fertiliser plants.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This datasets corresponds to the technology used in Chinese fertiliser plants. The production of diammonium phosphate involves the combination of liquid ammonia with phosphoric acid, using heat and electricity.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The data were extrapolated from respective data for the geography of Europe, i.e.  production of ammonia is adapted to reflect production in China.
